qas.question: Why are the buildings so shoddily built?
What did builder's use in place of steel rods as re-inforcement?
Who was supposed to inspect building to see if they met national standards?

context: On May 15, 2008 Geoffery York of the Globeandmail.com reported that the shoddily constructed buildings are commonly called "tofu buildings" because <a0_0>builders cut corners<a0_0/> by replacing steel rods with <a1_0>thin iron wires<a1_0/> for concrete re-inforcement; using inferior grade cement, if any at all; and using fewer bricks than they should. One local was quoted in the article as saying that "the <a2_0>supervising agencies<a2_0/> did not check to see if it met the national standards."
